abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Road Improvement and
            Traffic Safety Project for Turkey were as follows: the
            outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that in looking back at the experience
            gathered through this project, there are two major areas
            where lessons emerge: (i) the successful implementation of a
            rather complex traffic safety component involving several
            agencies; and, (ii) the approach taken by the project to
            influence governance issues in a sector prone to capture by
            strong vested interests. In particular: The Traffic Safety
            Experience - the design of this component was, from the
            outset, the result of a participatory exercise in which each
            organization involved in the project brought its own
            perspective to the traffic safety problem and proposed its
            own solutions. The individualistic approach to the issues at
            stake slowly evolved into a collegial system structured
            under the Task Force that was the key player in the
            implementation of the component. This accomplishment, not a
            minor feat in a country not known for inter-agency
            coordination, can be attributed to the adoption of the
            "best fit" rather than "best practice"
            approach. The Governance Issue - the project was prepared at
            a time in which the structural issues of governance were not
            as clearly recognized as today, maybe confusing capabilities
            (or lack thereof) with rent seeking behavior, and proposing
            institutional development rather than major policy reforms.
            The Bank's position of not participating in the
            financing, and therefore not condoning, the practice of
            continuous changes of design and cost overruns, was a step
            in the right direction given the relationship with Turkey at
            the time. A related question from which it might be possible
            to draw some useful lessons refers to the Bank's
            decision to deny a Government request to extend the life of
            the loan. At that time substantial human and financial costs
            had been sunk in the preparation of a fairly sophisticated
            Highway Information System.
